content:
本件保存七年
03-62- 2 3 3 5 1 MEMORANDUM
July 30, 2
To
: Mr. Wesley C. Haraldson, Director, US AID/C
From
: K. T. Ii, Secretary General Original signed by K. T. Li
Subject
: Recommendations in Audit Report No. A-1711
with reference to copy of Audit Report Ne. A-1711 to you dated May 18, 1962 in which some recommendations on de- livery, stockpiling and disposition of excess properties acquired under both Project Type and Non-Project Type Assistance are set forth, we wish to make the following comments and explanations:
The audit report concerning the Excess Equipment Project No. 99-471 appears to be basically same as its draft which had been sent to CUSA for clearance but was not cleared by CUSA on account of its being not entirely consistent with the facts and returned per CUSA letter C2-62-1433 under date of May 8, 1962. Therefore, our comments with regard to the recommendations listed in the said report are also basically same to what we have stated.
Regarding Recommendation (1) - BRS is the handling agency for excess equipment procured abroad under Project, No. 99-471 and keeps necessary records. On the part of CUSA, matters pertaining to this project are handled by its various offices in accordance with their respective functions. The Second Division of CUSA handles programming and allocation and has records as required; so do other CUSA offices. The detailed Arrival Report is now submitted by BES within about two weeks from the date of arrival. Considering the various steps necessary at the port and time required by BES for checking and listing, we think this is reasonable. No re- organization of the operating system is deemed necessary.
E-16.13.2
51.3. 100×200
國史馆 Academia Historica
67

MEMORANDUM
July 30,
To
: Mr. Wesley C. Haraldson, Director, US AID/C
From
: K. T. Ii, Secretary General
Original signed by
K. T. Li
Subject
: Recommendations in Audit Report No. A-1711
with reference to copy of Audit Report Ne. A-1711 to you
dated May 18, 1962 in which some recommendations on de-
livery, stockpiling and disposition of excess properties
acquired under both Project Type and Non-Project Type
Assistance are set forth, we wish to make the following
comments and explanations:
The audit report concerning the Excess Equipment Project
No. 99-471 appears to be basically same as its draft which
had been sent to CUSA for clearance but was not cleared by
CUSA on account of its being not entirely consistent with
the facts and returned per CUSA letter C2-62-1433 under
date of May 8, 1962. Therefore, our comments with regard
to the recommendations listed in the said report are also
basically same to what we have stated.
Regarding Recommendation (1) - BRS is the handling agency
for excess equipment procured abroad under Project, No.
99-471 and keeps necessary records. On the part of CUSA,
matters pertaining to this project are handled by its
various offices in accordance with their respective functions.
The Second Division of CUSA handles programming and allocation
and has records as required; so do other CUSA offices. The
detailed Arrival Report is now submitted by BES within about
two weeks from the date of arrival. Considering the various
steps necessary at the port and time required by BES for
checking and listing, we think this is reasonable. No re-
organization of the operating system is deemed necessary.

Academia Historica

paragraphs.content: : Mr. Wesley C. Haraldson, Director, US AID/C
: K. T. Ii, Secretary General Original signed by K. T. Li
: Recommendations in Audit Report No. A-1711

with reference to copy of Audit Report Ne. A-1711 to you dated May 18, 1962 in which some recommendations on de- livery, stockpiling and disposition of excess properties acquired under both Project Type and Non-Project Type Assistance are set forth, we wish to make the following comments and explanations:

The audit report concerning the Excess Equipment Project No. 99-471 appears to be basically same as its draft which had been sent to CUSA for clearance but was not cleared by CUSA on account of its being not entirely consistent with the facts and returned per CUSA letter C2-62-1433 under date of May 8, 1962. Therefore, our comments with regard to the recommendations listed in the said report are also basically same to what we have stated.

Regarding Recommendation (1) - BRS is the handling agency for excess equipment procured abroad under Project, No. 99-471 and keeps necessary records. On the part of CUSA, matters pertaining to this project are handled by its various offices in accordance with their respective functions. The Second Division of CUSA handles programming and allocation and has records as required; so do other CUSA offices. The detailed Arrival Report is now submitted by BES within about two weeks from the date of arrival. Considering the various steps necessary at the port and time required by BES for checking and listing, we think this is reasonable. No re- organization of the operating system is deemed necessary.
